column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=( ( WN ) )
#Text=There 's a lot of talk about Kim Jong-un being an inexperienced leader — do you think he knows where the ' brink ' lies ?
#Text=RK : That 's actually a really good question .
#Text=No , I do n't , which is why we 're having this whole conversation .
#Text=Kim 's father , Kim the second [ Kim Jong-il ] , was actually very good about this , " good " in quotations I suppose .
#Text=He knew really well how to play this game , he knew really well how to play the South , particularly for aid , rice , assistance , fuel , things like that .

#Text=The new guy — he 's only been in there for a year-and-a-half , right , 14 , 15 months — he did n't go through the grooming institutions of the regime , he did n't go through the military or the party .
#Text=And he certainly has no military training , it 's not like he went to some military institute — he went to some boarding school in Switzerland , or something like that .
#Text=So it 's not at all clear that this guy knows , sort of how this is done .

#Text=I have a feeling myself that he 's being egged on by the generals at home , and the generals are really doing this because they do not want the military 's position to be lowered in the new order .

#Text=Under the previous Kim , under the second Kim [ Kim-Jong-il ] , the military was raised in the constitution to a very high level of importance , they were sort of the primary pillar of the government , this is called the ' Military First ' policy .
#Text=I think people now worry that the new Kim — in order to re-start the economy might downgrade the role of the military , and I think that is where all this is coming from .
#Text=I do n't think they want a war .
#Text=( ( WN ) ) All of these threats , do you think they are just a way of getting more economic aid from the United Nations ?
#Text=RK : I would n't say the United Nations [ UN ] because the UN role in this is actually pretty minimal .

#Text=It is true that there are some UN specialized agencies that operate in North Korea — the World Food Programme I believe is the big one because North Korea constantly has food problems — and there are western NGOs , and aid groups , charities and stuff like that , also operate in North Korea .
#Text=I 've actually been to North Korea and I 've seen these charities operate .
#Text=I 've actually met some of the people who actually live there and do this stuff .
#Text=But they 're actually pretty small , right ? I mean , the North Koreans are pretty worried about Westerners running around in North Korea making trouble and saying things and this and that .
#Text=Any kind of foreign penetration in North Korea is very , very limited .
#Text=I think the real issue is actually North Korea 's neighbors , specifically Japan , China , the United States and South Korea .
#Text=Russia 's really sort of a bit player in this drama .
#Text=And that 's what they really want , the North Koreans now are very dependent on only the Chinese .
#Text=They used to be able to play the Chinese off the South Koreans off the Japanese off the Americans and extract aid and concessions from each of those .

#Text=In the last ten years or so it has become harder to do that — particularly Japan , the United States and South Korea have closed ranks and do n't really deal individually with North Korea anymore .
#Text=This has pushed North Korea to China .
#Text=North Korea does n't like being dependent on just one player .
#Text=And so I think that 's what this is an effort to shake up , [ ... ] a very difficult game for the North were they an economic colony of China .
